Motoring: Volvo V50 prays for a cold snap.


It was eight in the morning but it was still pitch dark. Outside, the snow was coming at us horizontally, blown by strong northerly winds.

The temperature gauge on the dashboard of Volvo's new V50 AWD said it was minus 8C - warm for early February 150 miles inside the Arctic Circle.

Ahead of us lay a route that would take us to almost within touching distance of the Russian border. If we could get through the three-kilometrewide exclusion zone, avoid being seen from the watch towers sited on nearby hills, all that lay between us andthe remnants of the Russian Navy's Northern Fleet at anchor in Murmansk was just under 200 miles of pine forest buried in winter snow.

This was Volvo's Winter Challenge - to pit machine against everything a harsh Scandinavian winter could throw at it.

We were based near Ivalo and a town perhaps best known as the home of Santa Claus to hundreds of children taken there by their parents to visit him in his workshop in the weeks running up to Christmas.

On test were a V8 powered version of Volvo's best-selling XC90 SUV and an all-wheeldrive derivative of the V50 estate car.

Available in left-hand drive only, there are no plans tobring the XC90 V8 to the UK. But at least it gave you a good indication of the 4x4 capability and agility of its smallerengined siblings, as well as the V50 AWD, on frozen routes as hard as graniteor on softer ploughed, knee deep snow.

Technical difficulties in fitting the transverse-mounted engine stop the Swedes from making the car into a righthand drive model. It will do well in its main US market, however, where an average fuel consumption of just under 21mpg will not deter buyersstill paying only pounds 1 a gallon.

The V50 AWD will go on sale in the UK, however, where I reckon it will do well against its rivals, the Jaguar X-Type Estate, the Audi A4 Avant quattro and BMW 3-Series Touring.

Available in Sport, SE and SE Sport trim levels, prices range from pounds 25,513 to pounds 27,363 on the road.

Power comes from a strong T5, five-cylinder 2.5-litre petrol engine with a light-pressure turbo which produces exceptional torque. The high, flat torque curve ensures great acceleration with 320Nm of torque available all the way from 1,500 to 4,800rpm -with a maximum output of220bhp. Acceleration from rest to 62mph takes only 7.2 seconds and top speed is 143mph (140mph auto).

The all-wheel-drive is the same Haldex system already fitted to Volvo's larger AWD models - the V70, XC70 and XC90.

Engine power is automatically distributed between the front and rear wheels with the help of an extremely fastresponding electricallyoperated hydraulic clutch which transmits maximum torque to the rear wheels even before the front wheels have rotated aquarter of a revolution.

This instant engagement and disengagement continues for consistent and stable road manners on all types of surface. In Finland, that meant ice and snow as well as snow-ploughed tarmac. Stability is boosted by theAWD system's extra weight over the rearwheels.

On a test track shared with half a dozen rally-prepared Subaru Imprezas, the V50 AWD showed just what it could do.

On the handling track carved out of hard-packed snow, and full of tricky corners, the rear of the car would start to break away but a correction on the steering wheel would bring it back into line.

The independent all-round suspension has spring struts at the front and a multi-link system at the rear which provides a certain degree of passive steering - helping to counteract any skid.

The car was equally impressive on a slalom. Keep a steady pressure on the accelerator and the car behaves as if it is stuck with glue.

Only when the driver forgets to be gentle with the throttle does the V50 show any tendency to send the back end out of line.

Accelerating hard in a straight line on the iceand slamming on the brakes should, you might think, send the car spinning all over the ice. It didn't. The car stayed true and never wavered.

The V50 isfitted with very powerful ABS brakes - with electronic brake force distribution to the rear wheels and automatic panic braking assistance - EBA (Energy Braking Assistance), plus Volvo's advanced DSTC (Dynamic Stability and Traction Control) asstandard.

The DSTC system automatically counteracts a skid as it starts by activating the brakes and/or reducing engine torque to help maintain driving control. However it does it, it works.

The return leg to Ivalo and a well-earned sauna included a 50-mile adventure along narrow, snow-smothered forest tracks.

In places, it was almost impossible to see where you had to go. Only the piles of snow at the side of the track where they had been pushed by a snowplough days, maybe weeks before indicated the way ahead.

A sudden twitch at the rear as the car found a hidden rut or icy patch was soon rectified by a responsive tug at the wheel.

Mistakes could be made. One car did get stuck and had to be pulled free after misreading a soft verge for the track, but that was driver error. The car itself behaved impeccably. It was an impressive display of how the V50 can cope with conditions farmore severe than anything Britain is ever likely to see.

Just what the doctor ordered, then, in this week's snow and ice

Alistair Coull
Birmingham Post
February 25, 2005
